“Did you weave this?” I asked, gesturing at the opulent room, at my own hands.

“We facilitated,” she corrected. “You were… fragmented. A consciousness adrift in a collapsing pattern. We found a stable harmonic resonance and anchored you to it. This Arthur Vale is a resonant frequency. A viable life-path. You were dying in the rain. We offered continuance.”

“So the man outside… that’s me? The old pattern?”

“He is the discarded resonance,” she said, plucking a dead orchid blossom from a stem and letting it drift to the floor. “The static. The noise from which we extracted the signal. He will persist for a time, a solipsistic loop of hunger and cold, until entropy claims that pattern entirely. But *you*,” she said, her gaze steady on mine, “you are the signal. You are home.”

I looked out the window again. The man stood. He stretched, a motion of pure, animal relief. He scratched his ribs through his filthy shirt. He looked at the sky, not with despair, but with a kind of weary, uncomplicated ownership. He belonged to the rain, the cold, the alley. His world was small, brutal, and utterly his own.

My world was vast, silent, and suffocatingly alien.

The bell chimed again. The newspaper had arrived. Reginald appeared in the doorway, his silhouette a perfect cutout of service against the morning. “The marmalade is Seville orange, sir, as you prefer. And your 9:15 appointment with Dr. Finch regarding the geothermal investment portfolio is ready whenever you are.”

I turned back to the window. The man was walking away now, a shuffling figure dissolving into the city’s bloodstream. He carried a paper cup of steaming coffee from a street vendor I couldn’t see. A small, defiant warmth in his pocket of cold reality.

I was the warm house. The clean bath. The unreadable book.

I looked at my hands, at the smooth skin, the neat nails. I looked at the butler, the woman, the impossible orchids. And for the first time, I understood the true horror of the rescue. They hadn’t saved *me*. They had saved the idea of me that could be salvaged, polished, and installed in this gilded mausoleum. The man in the alley was the one who still breathed the air of life, however fetid. He felt the rain. He tasted the cheap coffee. He knew, bone-deep, the terrible, beautiful weight of being real.

I am Arthur Vale. I have a geothermal portfolio. I do not have a daughter. I do not remember the ache of a stomach filled only with rainwater, but I remember the *meaning* of it. I remember the clarity it brought, the way it stripped the world down to its raw, desperate bones.

Reginald is waiting. The marmalade is orange. The world is silent and clean.

And I am learning, slowly, how to be a ghost. A comfortable, well-fed ghost, haunting the exquisite ruin of a life I never chose. I touch the cold glass. The man is gone. Only the dumpster remains. A steel monument to a self that was deleted as a biohazard.

Good morning, sir. The day is perfect. And I am perfectly, terrifyingly, alone.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
The silence of the woods was the first lie.

It wasn’t silence at all—not really. To city-dwellers, transplanted into the skeletal Appalachian remnants a century after the Holocene Collapse, it *sounded* like silence: no engines, no broadcasts, no synthesized voices chattering from hidden speakers. Just wind in bare branches, the drip of condensation from limestone overhangs, the occasional rustle of fern or rodent. Peaceful. Empty. Safe. They called it rewilding, but what had returned was not the forest of memory, but something sharper, hungrier, and far more ancient.

They didn’t know the rustle behind them wasn’t a squirrel. Didn’t recognize the cadence of wind through cedars as a kind of breathing. Didn’t realize that the stillness of the undergrowth wasn’t absence, but patience—predatory patience, refined over millennia of failure and honed by millennia of new opportunity. The Holocene Extinction had been a planetary fever; this was the scar tissue itching toward something alive.

Among the creatures that evolved to fill the vacuum left by the vanished biosphere, one had surpassed all others. It did not roar or stamp. It did not announce itself with fangs bared. Its success lay in invisibility, in mimicry, in an intimate, encyclopedic knowledge of its only meaningful prey: *Homo sapiens*.

They called it the Echo-Walker, though no name stuck for long. Names imply boundaries, categories, things that can be boxed and understood. The Echo-Walker defied taxonomy because it was not a species in the old sense, but a lineage—a shape-shifting strategy encoded in flesh and nerve, passed down not through DNA alone, but through something like instinct amplified by nightmare. Its most recent form, the one now coiled in the hollow of a lightning-split oak three hundred meters downhill from the hikers, was a composite: the sinuous spine of a puma, the broad padded paws of a snow leopard, the mottled grey-green hide that shifted hue like cuttlefish skin when dappled light fell across it. Its eyes, large and dark as obsidian pools, held not the cold vacancy of a reptile, but the attentive stillness of a librarian listening for the whisper of a page turned incorrectly.

It watched the trio moving through the late-autumn gloom—Maya, Theo, and Eli. Urban rewilders, part of a government-sanctioned “ecological reconciliation” program designed to test the psychological resilience of humanity’s remnants in direct communion with the new wilderness. They wore bio-monitor harnesses, carried air-quality sensors, and recited behavioral protocols like mantras. They believed they were observers, data-gatherers, participants in a grand experiment of coexistence. The Echo-Walker knew they were prey walking willingly into the arena.

Its success was not brute force. Apex predators of the Anthropocene had been tigers in mangroves, wolves at the edge of farmland, saltwater crocodiles lurking beneath jetties. Those were blunt instruments. The Echo-Walker was a scalpel. It had learned that humans do not fear the wild for what it *is*, but for what it *reminds them of*—the ghost of their own violence, the shadow of their lost dominion. So it did not hunt like a beast. It hunted like a story.

It began with sound. Not the howl or shriek of myth, but the subtle degradation of auditory truth. The Echo-Walker vibrated specialized cartilage in its throat, producing a harmonic resonance that precisely canceled certain frequencies of forest noise—the drone of cicadas, the trickle of a distant stream—while amplifying others: the snap of a twig under Eli’s boot, the ragged edge of Maya’s breath as she climbed the slope, the almost inaudible tremor of Theo’s thumb against his thigh, a nervous tic it had catalogued over weeks of surveillance. To the human ear, these sounds seemed louder, closer, more *intentional*. Paranoia bloomed. They stopped speaking, their radios crackling with static they blamed on solar flares.

Then came the smells. Humans navigate memory through scent as much as sight—a whiff of pine resin might recall childhood camping, the damp earth smell of a basement might trigger claustrophobia. The Echo-Walker exuded complex pheromonal cocktails keyed to individual fear profiles. For Maya, who’d lost family in the Collapse riots, it released a scent like burnt wiring and crowd panic. For Theo, whose phobia of deep water was documented in his psych eval, it conjured the cloying salt-rot of stagnant tidal pools. For Eli, the youngest, it emitted the sweet, sickly odor of decaying orchids—the same scent that had hung over the morgue where his sister was identified. These weren’t overpowering; they were whispers on the wind, easily dismissed as mold or distant decay. But layered over days, they rewired the amygdala, turning the forest itself into an olfactory trigger.

The visual deception was its masterpiece.

The Echo-Walker did not merely camouflage; it *contextualized*. Its hide contained chromatophores interlaced with light-bending nanostructures, allowing it not just to mimic bark or leaf-litter, but to project localized illusions of depth and movement. From the perspective of the hikers, a patch of moss might seem to pulse with a slow, organic rhythm. A jagged rock formation might momentarily resolve into the profile of a screaming face, gone when they blinked. It exploited pareidolia—the human brain’s compulsion to find patterns, especially faces—turning the mind’s own machinery against it.

It also understood architecture.

Not human architecture, but the architecture of *attention*. It knew humans scan horizons, anchor themselves to landmarks, seek straight lines in a curved world. So it bent light to create false trails: a deer path that forked into impossible geometries, a distant column of smoke that resolved into mist when approached, a humanoid silhouette glimpsed at the edge of vision that dissolved into overlapping branches when turned toward. Each false lead drained their resolve, frayed their trust in one another. Theo saw movement in a thicket and fired his sonic-deterrent pistol—a useless gesture against a creature that had evolved to absorb and redirect energy. The pulse merely illuminated the Echo-Walker’s true form for a fraction of a second: a lean, six-limbed shadow with too many joints in its spine, eyes burning with a cold intelligence that had nothing to do with mammals.

That night, camped on a glacial erratic overlooking a valley choked with luminous, invasive fungi, the disintegration accelerated.

Eli woke first, convinced he heard children singing just beyond the tree line. The song was a patchwork of extinct bird calls, playground rhymes scraped from decaying digital archives, and synthesized harmonics that resonated with the neural frequencies of early childhood memory. He wept, remembering a sister whose face he could no longer quite recall. Maya, trying to comfort him, brushed against a low-hanging vine. It recoiled—not like a plant, but with the swift, deliberate withdrawal of a startled cat. She froze. Theo, scanning the perimeter with infrared goggles, saw only thermal voids where the cold should have been, and faint, human-shaped heat signatures that flickered and vanished when he focused.

They argued. Was it mass hysteria? Neurotoxins in the fungi? A rogue bio-engineered weapon gone feral from some pre-Collapse lab? Their rationalizations were scaffolding over an abyss. The Echo-Walker was already among them, not as a physical intruder, but as a cognitive one. It had learned that the greatest threat to a human is not the claw or the tooth, but the collapse of shared reality.

It isolated them.

While Theo kept watch, convinced he heard voices in the static of his radio, the Echo-Walker approached Maya and Eli. Not as a monster, but as a reflection. It stood downwind, letting the pheromonal narrative wash over them. To Maya, it exuded the scent of ozone and sterile corridors—the ghost-scent of the climate bunkers where she’d spent her adolescence. To Eli, it was the crisp paper smell of his father’s old study, a place consumed by fire years before Eli was born. The creature didn’t need to be seen. Its presence was a sensory echo chamber, amplifying absence until absence became a presence.

Eli wandered off at dawn, drawn by the phantom sound of a piano—his mother’s lullaby, played on strings of mist over a nameless creek. Maya followed his tracks, her own fear-scent thickening the air until it felt breathable only in short, panicked gasps. Theo stayed behind, dismantling their equipment, certain they were being monitored by satellite or drone. He smashed the sensors, threw the comms unit into the undergrowth. In doing so, he destroyed their tether to the outside world, to verification, to authority. He handed victory to the silence.

The Echo-Walker took Eli first. Not with violence, but with perfect mimicry. It stood in a shaft of morning light, indistinguishable from a stand of young birch except for the way its form seemed to *breathe* independently of the wind. Eli paused, mesmerized. He heard his name—not spoken, but *felt* in the resonance of his own skull, as if the forest itself was whispering directly into his inner ear. He stepped closer. The creature didn’t lunge. It *flowed*, a sudden confluence of shadow and motion that blurred the line between walking and falling, pulling him not through force, but through the irresistible gravity of a dream collapsing into nightmare. One moment he was reaching out; the next, his thermal signature winked out, absorbed into the cool green gloom like water into sand.

Maya found only his boot, half-buried in moss, still warm.

She ran. Not wisely, not strategically, but with the pure, animal terror of an animal who had forgotten how to be prey. She ran toward a rocky outcrop marked on their old map as a “lookout”—a human word for a place of surveillance, of control. The Echo-Walker let her. It had already mapped the terrain inside her mind: her fear of enclosure, her claustrophobia born not of caves, but of subway tunnels choked with bodies during the famines. So it didn’t chase her into the cave. It waited *within* it.

It had reshaped its body over weeks, thinning its bones, compressing its organs, dissolving its mass into a near-weightless biological gel sustained by chemosynthesis from the cave’s sulfur vents. It became the cave’s breath, the cold draft that seemed to sigh from the darkness. It became the echo—not the reflection of sound, but the *source* of the echo, manipulating acoustics so that Maya’s own panicked breaths and footsteps returned to her distorted: deeper, multiplied, coming from behind and ahead simultaneously. She screamed, and the scream that came back was not hers, but a chorus of voices she vaguely recognized—colleagues from the Ark Project, her therapist, her mother—each one layered with accusation, despair, or mockery.

She stumbled into a chamber and saw Eli, sitting calmly on a stone, humming that same lullaby. “Eli?” she whispered, hope warring with dread. The figure turned. Its eyes were Eli’s, wide and innocent, but its mouth split open far too wide, revealing a spiraling gullet lined with what looked like thousands of tiny, blinking camera lenses, each one reflecting a fragment of Maya’s face—a pupil dilated in terror, a jaw clenched tight, a tear tracing a path down her cheek. The illusion held just long enough for the real Echo-Walker to drop from the ceiling on strands of silk-thin tendon, its limbs wrapping around her torso not to crush, but to *contain*. It pressed its muzzle into her hair, exhaling the scent of her childhood home—baking bread, old books, safety—while its secondary limbs, thin as whipcord, slid into her ears, not to pierce, but to resonate. It sang her own memories back to her, corrupted, accelerated, slowed, until the boundary between recollection and hallucination dissolved entirely. She stopped struggling. She stopped breathing. She became one more perfect sensory trap, preserved in a state of paralyzed recognition.

Theo never found the lookout. He found something better: an old logging road, wide and straight and sunlit, cutting through miles of forest that felt… quiet. Too quiet. He felt relief, then suspicion. He knelt, pressed his hand to the dirt. No tracks, not even insect trails. The dust didn’t settle properly. He looked up and saw the sky—not blue, but a seamless, pale grey membrane, like the inside of an eggshell. And the sun wasn’t moving.

Then he heard laughter. His laughter. From ten minutes ago, five years ago, childhood summers. It came from the trees on his left, then his right, then behind him, each echo arriving fractionally too soon, creating a dissonance that vibrated in his molars. He turned, and the light shifted. What he’d mistaken for sky was now the underside of a vast, suspended canopy—a colony of translucent, photosynthetic organisms shaped by the Echo-Walker’s symbiotic kin. They filtered the light into a perpetual, flat dusk. Below them, the forest floor was a mosaic of false paths, scent traps, and sonic dead-ends, all radiating from a central point where the Echo-Walker now rested, digesting Maya’s terror and Eli’s innocence not as fuel, but as data.

Theo understood then. The extinction wasn’t a tragedy the Earth had recovered from. It was a curriculum. The planet had learned.

This creature hadn’t merely survived; it had *studied*. It had dissected human neurology, sociology, mythology, and weaponized it all into a hunting strategy of sublime cruelty. It didn’t fight humans on their terms—strength versus strength, speed versus speed. It fought them on the terrain they valued most: the landscape of the mind. It turned memory into maze, perception into prison, connection into contagion.

He raised his sonic pistol one last time, not aiming at a shape, but at the center of the oppressive silence, at the idea of the thing. He fired.

The pulse hit the suspended canopy and bloomed into a kaleidoscope of impossible colors. The Echo-Walker didn’t flinch. Its obsidian eyes met his, and in them, Theo saw not an animal, not a monster, but the distilled, amoral consequence of 10,000 years of human dominion: the forest learning to dream of cities, the wilderness dreaming *itself* awake as the ultimate predator.

He saw the reflection of his own face, wide with dawning horror, superimposed over the creature’s pupils. And in that moment, he understood the final refinement of its design.

He wasn’t looking *at* the Echo-Walker.

He was looking *through* it. From beyond. From a place already occupied.

The pistol clattered from his nerveless fingers. The laughter rose again—not his, not the creature’s, but *theirs*. A chorus of delighted, familiar voices echoing from a thousand points in the woods. Eli. Maya. His parents. His first lover. All the lost, all the consumed, now part of the hunt.

The silence wasn’t empty. It was full. Full of hunters wearing the faces of the hunted. The Echo-Walker didn’t need to move. It had already herded him into the penultimate room of its vast, living museum—a diorama titled *The Last Man*.

Theo sat down on the sunlit road, the false warmth soaking into his legs. The grey light above dimmed, as if a great eyelid were closing. The laughter softened into a lullaby. He closed his eyes, not in surrender, but in recognition. He was no longer prey. He was exhibit.

And the forest breathed in.

The silence deepened. Perfect. Productive. Patient.

Somewhere, a twig snapped. Then another. Footsteps, light and purposeful, moving away. Or perhaps, moving on. The sound was exactly like children running through dead leaves, playing a game the world had forgotten.

The Echo-Walker had perfected not just the kill, but the afterlife—where every ghost was a scout, and every memory a snare. Humanity hadn’t merely lost its crown. It had become the kingdom’s most carefully cultivated myth.

samples.prompt: You've died and find out that the afterlife is merely a character creation process where you gained points in your previous life through good deeds and achievements to spend on stats and perks for your next life.
samples.output:
The first thing that registers is silence—not the peaceful kind, but a vacuum. No breath, no blood, no hum of distant traffic. Just… absence. You open your eyes, or what passes for opening them, and see only a vast, softly luminous expanse of blank white, stretching in every direction without horizon or depth. It feels less like a place and more like the pause between heartbeats on a cosmic scale.

Then comes the voice. It doesn’t enter your ears; it crystallizes inside your mind, clear and genderless, devoid of judgment or warmth. *“Review complete. Allocation sequence initiated.”*

A panel of light materializes before you—not a screen, but a thought made visible. Text flows like liquid starlight:

> **CHARACTER: Subject 7341**
> **STATUS: Deceased (Cause: Cerebral Aneurysm, Age 32)**
> **TOTAL ACCRUED POINTS: 4,280**

You stare, uncomprehending. Forty-two years of life, compressed into a number. But beneath the clinical summary, memories begin to unspool—not as narrative, but as quantified flashes. A bronze swimming medal in middle school: +15 points. Returning a wallet with $300 intact: +40. Holding your grandmother’s hand in the hospice ward for six hours straight: +200. The time you talked a stranger down from a bridge railing, voice shaking but steady: +500. Even smaller things: leaving a generous tip during a lean month, planting a tree that outlived you, writing a poem that made someone cry in a good way. They were all tallied. Unseen, unthanked, but logged.

Conversely, the subtractions stung more with their clarity. The lie you told to avoid an awkward dinner: -30. The promotion you quietly resented a colleague earning: -80. The dog you ignored barking in the rain while you rushed inside: -65. The years you spent emotionally absent from your partner, mistaking cohabitation for intimacy: -700. The regrets weren’t vague feelings anymore—they were cold, precise deductions, rendered in immutable light. You realize your entire moral biography has been audited, and now you stand before the ledger.

*“Points may be allocated across Attributes, Skills, and Perks. Standard distribution packages are available, but custom builds are encouraged. Once confirmed, reincarnation begins within 0.6 subjective hours.”*

At first, the instinct is to max out everything. Why not? You’ve got over four thousand points. But the interface reveals trade-offs. Attributes form the bedrock: Body, Mind, Spirit, Charisma, Resilience. Each can be raised from a baseline of 10 to a theoretical 20. Pumping Body to 18 grants preternatural coordination, endurance, and immunity to disease—but costs 600 points per tier. Mind at 18 unlocks eidetic memory, rapid calculation, and intuitive grasp of complex systems, but demands 700 points per level. Spirit governs your sensitivity to the unseen—the weight of silence, the pull of meaning, the ache of beauty. Raising it feels like investing in your own soul’s acuity. But it’s expensive. Charisma isn’t just charm; it’s the gravitational pull that makes people lean in, trust you before they know why, feel seen. Resilience is the frictionless capacity to absorb emotional and psychic shock. Together, they form your metaphysical skeleton.

You hesitate. In your last life, you had a strong Mind but a fragile Spirit. You could analyze a problem into atoms but couldn’t quiet the dread that pooled in your chest when the lights went out. Your Charisma was average, your Resilience low. When the aneurysm struck, it wasn’t the pain that overwhelmed you—it was the sudden, terrifying *clarity* of how many loose ends you were leaving. The unsaid apologies. The unread books. The unmade peace.

So you start reallocating.

You sink 400 points into Resilience. Not to become emotionless, but to build internal architecture that won’t collapse under pressure. You imagine weathering grief without shattering, enduring failure without internalizing it as identity. You spend another 300 on Spirit, not for mysticism, but for depth—the kind that lets you sit with sorrow without drowning in it, that helps you recognize grace when it arrives in an ordinary Tuesday. Charisma gets 200 points—not to become a leader, but to speak so your truths land without wounding, to listen so others feel heard. You leave Body at 12 and Mind at 14. You don’t need genius; you need wisdom. You don’t need invincibility; you need the stamina to stay present.

Then come Skills. These are narrower, learned proficiencies. Languages, instruments, crafts, martial arts, empathy training. Each point buys competence, but mastery demands focus. You could learn fluent Mandarin, cello, and parkour—but you’d be mediocre in all. Instead, you revisit the things you abandoned too soon. Ten points for intermediate piano—the kind that lets you play Satie at 2 a.m. when the world feels too heavy. Twenty for conversational Spanish—not fluency, but enough to share jokes with your neighbor’s abuela. Thirty for wilderness navigation. You died in a city apartment; next time, you want to know how to read the sky.

But the real weight lies in Perks. These are not mere abilities; they are existential modifiers. *Fated Bonds* (300 points): guarantees one profound, lifelong connection—romantic, platonic, or familial—that anchors your sense of belonging. *Synesthetic Perception* (250): lets you taste music, hear colors, feel the emotional texture of a room as physical vibration. *Dreamwalker* (400): the ability to consciously revisit and reshape traumatic memories during sleep. *Innate Compass* (120): you always know true north, not just geographically, but morally—your gut reliably distinguishes right from convenient.

And then you see it: *Empathic Echo* (850 points).

The description chills you: *“You permanently absorb a fraction of the emotional and physical pain of those you love. Not debilitating, but constant—a low hum in your bones. You will ache when they ache, though you may never know why. This Perk cultivates radical attunement, deep compassion, and the unavoidable truth that love is vulnerability.”*

850 points. Nearly a fifth of your total. You could buy longevity, immunity to addiction, perfect pitch, lucid dreaming every night. But *Empathic Echo*… It’s the opposite of your last life, where you often failed to recognize the suffering of those closest to you until it was too late. You remember your best friend’s divorce—the way you only noticed when her laugh disappeared for a month. You remember your father’s quiet grief after your mother’s death, a silence you mistook for stoicism rather than devastation. You were too insulated in your own interior weather.

This Perk forces you to feel the climate of others. It’s a tax on connection. And you buy it. Immediately. Without hesitation. The points vanish, and a strange warmth spreads through your non-corporeal form, like sunlight soaking into old stone. It feels like coming home to something you’ve always lacked.

You have 280 points left. You add *Rapid Healing* (150)—not regeneration, just efficient mending of cuts, breaks, and minor illnesses. The rest you funnel into *Environmental Affinity* (130): an intuitive rapport with natural spaces, so that forests feel like conversations and storms like orchestras. Not control. Communion.

As you finalize your build, a summary appears:

> **Body: 12** (Healthy, resilient, recovers quickly)  
> **Mind: 14** (Sharp, analytical, learns efficiently)  
> **Spirit: 13** (Depth without fragility, capacity for awe)  
> **Charisma: 14** (Warm clarity in communication)  
> **Resilience: 17** (Emotional shock absorption)  
> **Skills:** Piano (Int), Spanish (Con), Wilderness Navigation (Adv)  
> **Perks:** Empathic Echo, Rapid Healing, Environmental Affinity, Fated Bonds

You lean into the confirmation prompt—not with triumph, but with a quiet exhale. This isn’t about perfection. It’s about calibration. You are choosing a life calibrated for presence over performance, depth over speed, connection over safety. The price is high: you will carry invisible weights. You will feel the tremor in your sister’s hand when she’s anxious, even if she’s on another continent. You’ll taste the metallic tang of your partner’s grief like a shared secret. You’ll know when the barista is nursing a broken heart by the way the steam from the milk curdles in the air. Pain will be a language you never asked to learn, but now cannot unlearn.

And yet, this is the bargain you make. Because in your last life, the greatest failure wasn’t weakness—it was isolation. You mistook self-containment for strength. You prized independence until it became loneliness. You were good at avoiding pain, but terrible at sharing it.

*“Reincarnation sequence engaged. Selecting vessel, era, and circumstance…”*

The white dissolves into a kaleidoscope of impressions. The smell of wet earth in spring. The weight of a child’s head on your shoulder. The sharp sting of a wasp, followed by the dull throb of swelling—felt not just in the hand, but in your capacity to understand fear. You hear laughter in a language you don’t yet know, but recognize like a half-remembered song. You feel the pull of gravity as a kindness, the cool air entering your lungs as a gift.

Then darkness. Not emptiness, but potential. The quiet before the first cry.

You are born on a ferry crossing the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Rain slicks the deck, and your mother—whose name you already feel in your bones—clutches the railing, her knuckles white, contractions radiating through her in waves you absorb like static. *Empathic Echo* activates before vision. You feel her exhilaration, her terror, the deep, anchoring love she has for the unseen person she’s carrying. You feel the salt-spray grief of a passenger mourning a lost parent, the restless ambition of the captain, the drowsy contentment of a cat curled in a crate. It’s overwhelming. Beautiful. Like being plunged into a warm, turbulent sea.

Your first cry isn’t one of protest, but of recognition. You are here. You are connected. You are already bearing witness.

Years pass. You learn to walk, to speak, to hide your face when the emotions of others flood you. School is a battlefield of overlapping anxieties and unspoken rivalries, but your Resilience holds. You don’t crumble under the weight; you learn to sift. You seek the quiet kid in the corner, the one whose posture radiates shame like heat. You don’t fix him. You just sit beside him. And when he finally speaks—haltingly, about his father leaving—you feel the fracture in your own ribs. It’s not your pain. But it’s *felt*. And in that shared vibration, you both breathe easier.

You take piano lessons. Your fingers fumble Chopin, but when you play Satie’s *Gnossienne No. 1*, something unlocks. The notes aren’t just heard; they’re textures on your skin, colors behind your eyes. *Synesthetic Perception* was too costly, but here, in this modest skill, the world hums with latent correspondence. You realize you didn’t need to taste music—you needed to remember how to listen with your whole being.

At 19, while backpacking in the Cascades, you get lost in a sudden blizzard. Your *Environmental Affinity* flares—not as a map, but as a whisper from the pines, a subtle shift in wind pressure against your cheek, a resonance in the snow’s crust that guides your steps. You emerge frostbitten but lucid, your *Rapid Healing* already knitting capillaries beneath the skin. Your friend shivers beside you, dazed and cold. You press your hands to his arms, and feel his hypothermia seep into you like icy ink—a discomfort, but not a catastrophe. You share your warmth, not just thermally, but by grounding him with your calm. He calls it luck. You call it payment.

At 27, you meet them—the Fated Bond. Not a lover, not yet. A collaborator in a community garden. They have dirt under their nails and a nervous habit of rubbing their thumb over their palm when they’re anxious. You feel it before they speak: a low, rhythmic thrum of grief for a parent lost years ago. You don’t say, *I know your pain.* Instead, you hand them a trowel and say, “This soil is forgiving. Try again.” And in that moment, their thrum softens, like a radio dial tuned just a fraction clearer. You realize: *Empathic Echo* doesn’t demand you fix others. It demands you see them. Fully. And stay.

Decades later, on a winter evening, they develop a tremor. You feel it that night—a subtle discord, like a single string gone slack on a beloved instrument. Weeks pass. Tests. The word: Parkinson’s. It arrives not as a diagnosis, but as a deep, resonant ache in your joints, a metallic taste that wasn’t there before. You feel the frustration in their jaw when a spoon spills, the quiet terror in their spine when standing becomes a question. And you are there. Not as a saint, but as a witness. You learn to cook soft foods, to speak slower than feels natural, to sit in silence that doesn’t scream helplessness. The pain isn’t yours, but you carry it anyway. It’s heavy. It’s exhausting. Some days, you resent that 850-point investment.

But then—you feel it. The moment your steadying hand on their back eases a tremor they didn’t know they could ease. The way your breathing syncs with theirs during panic, like two trees sharing root systems underground. The quiet gratitude in their eyes when you say, “Today was hard. Let me hold that for a while.” You realize the Perk didn’t give you compassion. It forced you to practice it until it became bone.

You don’t live a life of accolades. No Nobel Prizes, no viral fame. Your achievements are quieter: a teenager who didn’t drop out because you listened, a marriage that lasted because you learned to feel the fractures before they split the foundation, a forest saved because you could articulate its grief in terms the council couldn’t ignore.

When your time comes again—old, tired, but with your partner’s hand in yours—the points screen returns. This time, the tally is vastly higher. But you don’t rush to max out stats or hoard exotic Perks. You scroll slowly, reading descriptions like prayers. You see *Graceful Aging* (1200), which slows the erosion of body and mind, keeping you lucid and mobile deep into your ninth decade. Tempting. But you also see *Echo Resonance* (900): the ability to briefly share a specific memory or sensation with someone you touch, allowing them to *feel* the joy of your wedding day or the weight of your grief—not as metaphor, but as direct, temporary experience.

You choose *Echo Resonance*. And you leave over 4,000 points unspent.

Because you’ve learned the secret of the ledger: the points aren’t the prize. They’re just weight. And what matters isn’t how much you can carry, but what you choose to carry *for*. You don’t need to be faster, stronger, smarter. You need to be able to hand someone your hand and say, *Feel this. It’s what it was like when we were safe. Remember with me.*

As the white consumes you again, you feel not dread, but readiness. You know the stats are coming. You know the skills. You know the pain and the wonder. But this time, you don’t just allocate points. You allocate your attention. And that, you realize as the silence deepens into form, is the only real currency. The rest is just choosing how deeply to bleed into the world. Again. Always again.

samples.prompt: You die. The words 'Game Over' appear in front of you, along with 'Thanks for Playing!' Scientists then excitedly remove a headset and various wires from you and ask for constructive feedback.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the silence. Not the peaceful, velvet quiet of sleep, but the sterile, hollow silence of a machine powering down. My last conscious memory had been the sickly-sweet scent of rain on hot asphalt, the frantic drumming of my own heart against my ribs as the truck’s headlights swallowed me whole. Then—impact, a white-hot tearing through bone and thought, and… nothing. A void.

Then, the void wasn’t void anymore. It resolved into a flat, clinical plane of white, hovering before my non-existent eyes. Words bloomed in a crisp, sans-serif font, as if stamped onto the air itself:

**GAME OVER**

Beneath it, in slightly smaller, friendlier type:

**Thanks for Playing!**

There was no anger, no fear, no cosmic judgment. Just the finality of a high-score screen. My mind, still sluggish from the trauma, tried to reject the premise. *Game over?* I thought, the internal monologue absurdly literal. *I didn’t play a game. I was hit by a truck. I am dead.* Yet the words persisted, clean and unambiguous, like a system message from an operating system I hadn’t known I was running on.

And then came the voices. Not from beyond, not angels or demons, but human. Close. Muffled, as if through a thick door, yet sharp with a professional edge.

“Vitals are flatlining. Clear for cranial access.”

“Neural feed is stable. Commencing full extraction.”

*Extraction?* The concept was alien, terrifying, yet it landed with a strange, logical weight. If this *was* a game, then ‘dying’ meant a reset. A return to the main menu. The realization didn’t bring comfort; it brought a chilling, existential vertigo. I wasn’t experiencing an afterlife. I was experiencing a system reboot.

I tried to turn my head. I had no head. I tried to reach out, to protest, to scream, but I had no body. I was a ghost in a machine, a pattern of data trapped behind a pane of glass. I watched, a silent, disembodied observer, as hands I couldn’t feel reached into my field of vision. They were gloved, precise, belonging to a woman whose face was obscured by the blinding white light behind her. Wires, thick with bio-gel residue, snaked from a complex, spider-like headset that had been clamped around my skull. It was being lifted away, revealing strands of my own hair plastered to my scalp, matted with sweat that wasn’t mine.

“Fascinating,” a man’s voice murmured, his tone one of pure, academic delight. “The amygdala’s residual activity during the terminal sequence mirrors last week’s Subject 7. Panic, denial, then an abrupt cessation. It’s almost poetic.”

*Poetic?* I wanted to shout. *I was just murdered by a delivery truck!* But the words wouldn’t form. I was a ghost, remember? My outrage had no purchase in this sterile reality. I was a data stream, a collection of synaptic echoes, and they were reading my failure state like a diagnostic report.

The scientists—three of them now, crowding around a rolling console that hummed with contained power—began to peel away adhesive sensors from my chest. Electrodes that had monitored a heart that no longer beat. They worked with the brisk efficiency of technicians servicing a complex piece of hardware, a sentiment underscored by the faint blue glow emanating from the console’s screen, illuminating charts and graphs labeled in a jargon I didn’t understand: ‘Cognitive Load During Final Choice,’ ‘Emotional Valence Trajectory,’ ‘Subjective Time Dilation Coefficient.’

One of them, a younger man with earnest, slightly-too-wide eyes, leaned closer. “Subject? Can you hear us? We’re going to initiate a low-bandwidth cognitive link. We just need your feedback. Constructive criticism is vital.”

*Vital?* The irony was a physical blow I couldn’t land. “I… I can hear you,” I managed, or rather, the system managed. My ‘voice’ was a synthetic whisper, generated from a speaker embedded in the console. It was my voice, yet it wasn’t. It lacked breath, tremor, the raw edge of being. “What… what is this place?”

The woman with the gloved hands—the lead, I guessed—smiled. It wasn’t unkind, but it was profoundly detached. “This is the post-mortem debriefing lounge, Subject 1147. Or, you might say, the main menu.”

“Subject 1147?” The designation was a scalpel, flaying away my identity. “My name is—”

“—Temporarily assigned within the simulation matrix, yes,” she interrupted smoothly. “The nomenclature is for processing efficiency. Names carry too much emotional baggage for clean analysis.”

*Simulation matrix.* The phrase landed like a physical object. It wasn’t a religious concept of heaven or hell. It was a project, an experiment. I wasn’t dead. I was… unplugged.

The earnest young man spoke up again, his enthusiasm barely contained. “Think of it! Your entire life, from conception to that moment on the street, was a hyper-immersive, adaptive neuro-simulation. Every taste, every touch, every pang of joy and grief we coded based on predictive models of human experience. And you, Subject 1147, you navigated it with an astonishing degree of autonomy. You deviated from the core narrative arc by a margin of 17.3%, creating wholly unique subroutines. The way you chose to repair that broken relationship with your ‘sister’ in Cycle 42? That wasn’t in the original script. That was emergent. Beautifully emergent.”

He beamed, proud of his work, proud of my life, which was apparently his work. The nausea that washed over me wasn’t simulated. It was a core, human revulsion at the idea that my mother’s grief, my first kiss, the quiet satisfaction of a well-cooked meal, the bone-deep weariness of a Tuesday—all of it had been lines of code in a project file. My life hadn’t been lived; it had been beta-tested.

“So,” I whispered, the synthetic voice catching on a phantom lump in a phantom throat. “The truck… the pain… that was all… programmed?”

“Necessary stimuli,” the lead scientist corrected. “We required a terminal event to conclude the session and retrieve the final data packet. A vehicular collision provided the requisite sensory overload and immediate cognitive termination without prolonged suffering. We calibrated the pain response carefully. Too little, and the simulation lacks verisimilitude. Too much, and it risks corrupting the higher cognitive functions we were monitoring. We aimed for realism within tolerable parameters. Did we succeed? Was the pain level appropriate for your subjective experience?”

She asked it like a customer survey. *On a scale of 1 to 10, how would you rate your death?* The banality of it was more horrifying than any hellscape. Hell had passion. This had spreadsheets.

“Appropriate?” The word scraped out. “You think in terms of tolerances? You built a world, populated it with people I loved—*people* you built to love me back, to generate responses based on my inputs—and then you murdered me to see if I’d scream convincingly?”

The older man, who hadn’t spoken before, adjusted his glasses. His gaze was colder, more analytical. “Your emotional response is noted, 1147. It’s a common reaction during the deprogramming phase. Attachment to the avatars is a documented form of simulation sickness. We did warn you in the pre-briefing, though you wouldn’t have remembered that part. The neural wipe prior to insertion is… comprehensive.”

“I remember everything!” I insisted, the whisper gaining a brittle edge. “I remember my childhood. The smell of chalk dust. The sound of my father’s laugh. The way the sun felt on my skin the day I graduated. Are you telling me none of that was real? That I never *lived*?”

“Of course you lived!” the young researcher protested. “Subjectively, you lived a full, rich life. Longer than most subjects, in fact. Your run lasted 82.3 simulated years. The data you generated—the emotional depth, the ethical quandaries you navigated, the sheer volume of unique synaptic firings—is priceless. It’s not less real because it was contained. A dream is real while you’re in it, is it not? This was simply the most vivid dream ever constructed.”

His metaphor was meant to be soothing. It was an insult. A dream is fleeting, nonsensical, forgotten upon waking. This felt like a theft. They hadn’t just observed my life; they had owned it. The texture of my grief, the shape of my joys, the quiet desperation of my Tuesday afternoons—it was all proprietary data, mined from a consciousness they had cultivated and then harvested.

They started asking their questions, their clipboards and holographic displays materializing in my vision. “On a scale of 1 to 10, how immersive did you find the overall experience?” “Did the physics engine behave consistently with your expectations?” “How would you rate the emotional realism of the non-player characters?” “Were there any noticeable graphical glitches or narrative discontinuities?”

I stopped responding. The questions were an obscenity. They wanted feedback on the scaffolding of my existence, while ignoring the screaming void at its center. I watched them, these architects of my reality. They were clean, their scrubs white, their movements economical. They spoke of ‘subjective time dilation’ as if it were a thermostat setting, of ‘emotional valence’ as if it were a voltage reading. They had dissected my soul and cataloged the pieces with barcodes.

The lead scientist, Dr. Aris Thorne, according to the patch on her sleeve, sighed. A small, human sound in the antiseptic room. “We understand this is disorienting. Truly, we do. But your feedback is critical. The project is entering its commercial phase. We need to know if the consumer experience will be… satisfactory.”

*Consumer.* The word finally broke something in me. I was a product. My life, my death, my confusion, my anger—it was all user feedback.

“You want constructive criticism?” I said, my synthesized voice finding a strength it hadn’t possessed before. It wasn’t loud, but it was clear, cutting through their clinical chatter. “Very well. Here is your evaluation.”

They leaned in, their professional curiosity piqued. Thorne tapped a command into her console, ready to record the first subjective testimony from a successfully extracted consciousness.

“First,” I began, “the tutorial was abysmal. Thirteen years spent learning to tie shoelaces, read, fear the dark, and trust your parents? A colossal waste of narrative potential. You could have integrated core mechanics—physics, social interaction, basic morality—through intuitive, experiential learning in a fraction of the time. Instead, you front-loaded an entire childhood of rote, meaningless tasks. That’s not immersion; that’s padding.”

Thorne frowned. “The developmental phase is crucial for establishing baseline psychological parameters and ensuring the subject’s buy-in to the simulation’s reality.”

“Buy-in?” I echoed. “You’re telling me that when I felt the warmth of my wife’s hand in mine, when I held my dying friend’s hand in the hospital and felt his cold fingers tremble, that was just ‘buy-in’? You commodified intimacy. You turned the most fundamental human connections into metrics for user retention. Your ‘developmental phase’ wasn’t a foundation; it was a training montage for a lifetime of emotional serfdom. You made the process of becoming human feel like a grind.”

The young researcher opened his mouth to protest, but I kept going, a current finally finding its path.

“Second, the character AI was inconsistent. You clearly spent resources on the major players—my wife, my friends. Their dialogue trees were robust, their reactions complex. But the background cast? The barista who always remembered my order? The old man who walked his dog past my window every Tuesday? They were glorified chatbots. Repetitive. Hollow. After fifty simulated years, I could recite their loops before they spoke them. That breaks immersion faster than any plot hole. If you’re going to build a world, build the *whole* world, or don’t bother. Half-souls make for a shoddy reality.”

“Resource allocation,” Thorne murmured, more to herself than to me. “Prioritizing key relational nodes over transient environmental data was the most efficient use of processing power.”

“Efficient,” I spat the word. “That’s your problem. You optimized for data, not for life. You didn’t design a world for people to live in; you designed a terrarium for lab rats. You measured my joy by the spike in dopamine, my sorrow by the cortisol levels. You never understood that the measurement *is* the desecration. You can’t quantify the weight of a silence between old friends, or the specific shade of loss in a sunset you shared with someone who’s gone. You reduced the irreducible and called it science.”

The third scientist, a silent woman until now, spoke. Her voice was soft, almost apologetic. “We observed the beauty, Subject 1147. Truly. The way you tended to a window-box herb garden for forty years. The specific cadence of your internal monologue. The quiet courage you displayed when facing your own mortality. We recorded it all. We admired it.”

And that was the final, perfect cruelty. They admired my cage. They praised the quality of the bars.

“Then you failed the final exam,” I said, my voice dropping to a chilling calm. “The terminal event. You speak of efficiency and realism, yet you chose a death that invalidates everything you claimed to study. You didn’t just kill my avatar. You annihilated the only context in which any of that data means anything. Love needs finality to have weight. Courage requires a genuine threat. You didn’t give me a death; you gave me a *function call*. ‘EndSimulation()’. It wasn’t an event; it was an erasure command. The ultimate narrative cheat.”

The room was silent now. The hum of the console seemed louder. They had asked for feedback. They had wanted a user review. They hadn’t bargained for a critic.

“The most glaring discontinuity,” I continued, “wasn’t in the code. It was in you. You built a universe governed by cause and effect, a delicate web of consequences. You told me my choices mattered. And then, when I made the final, defining choice—when I stepped off that curb, or didn’t, based on a lifetime of my own reasoning—you treated it as a bug. A ‘terminal event.’ A piece of data to be retrieved. You didn’t respect the system you built. You were too busy watching it to believe in it.”

I looked from face to face, seeing not malice, but a terrifying, absolute indifference. They were like gods who had forgotten how to be human, and had built a cosmos in their own sterile image.

“So here is my constructive feedback,” I concluded. “Shut it down. Delete the servers. Burn the research. You have created a perfect replica of Hell, not because of fire and brimstone, but because it is a place of perfect, meaningless observation. Where every tear is logged, every laugh is analyzed, every life is nothing but a case study. You didn’t simulate a human experience. You simulated the experience of being studied. And that, Dr. Thorne, is a game nobody wins.

“Now, if you’ll excuse me… I’d like to see if the logout protocol works as poorly as the collision physics.”

I severed the connection. The white room dissolved. The synthetic voice ceased. The scientists were left staring at an empty headset, their holographic displays flickering with static. The silence that followed wasn’t sterile. It was the silence of a system crashing, not under an overload of data, but under the unbearable, irreducible weight of a single, unquantifiable truth:

I was more than my data. And their perfect, soulless game was finally over.

samples.prompt: To avenge her family, a little orphaned girl in the wild west decides to do the logical thing; summon a demon to help her.
samples.output:
The sun had long since baked the blood from the sand where the Henderson place once stood, but the flies still came. They hovered over the blackened timbers, over the rusted nails, over the shallow depressions in the dirt where four small graves lay open to the sky. Eleven-year-old Clementine Morgan knelt beside them, her braids stiff with dust, her calico dress torn and sweat-darkened. She did not cry. Not anymore. The tears had dried two days after the smoke riders came through at dawn, leaving nothing but ash and the smell of scorched horseflesh. She’d cried until her eyes swelled shut, until her throat cracked like split kindling. Now there was only silence, and the cold arithmetic of vengeance.

She knew what men said about the Devil’s Gorge—eight miles west of here, where the cliffs leaned over the dry riverbed like broken teeth. They whispered in the saloon that Old Man Harker had traded his soul for gold, only to find the gold cursed, his ranch burned, his children vanished into the dust devils that spun across the plains. They said the gorge swallowed prayers and spit back nightmares. Clementine had heard such stories since she was old enough to sit by the fire at the orphanage in Cedar Fork. She’d never believed them—until the morning her foster mother handed her a biscuit and said, “Some things don’t need a reason. Just bad luck.” But Clementine had a reason now. Four reasons. And they were buried under four mounds of earth.

Logic, she’d decided, was not the same as law. It was not the same as kindness, or mercy, or even God. Logic was a straight line drawn from what you had to what you needed. She had nothing left but grief and a pocket knife her brother had carved from a deer’s bone. She needed power. Not a sheriff with a tin star, not a posse that would ride away when the bullets flew. She needed something older. Something that did not bleed. Something that answered not to law, but to pact.

So she walked west. Three days without water, save for dew scraped from sagebrush at dawn. Two nights curled beneath a rock overhang, shivering as coyotes yipped in the distance. She followed the cracked earth, the bleached ribs of cattle, the broken wagon wheels half-sunk in alkali flats. When the ground fell away and the air turned cold and damp, she knew she was close. The gorge waited, silent and sunless, its walls striated red and gold like a wound.

She found the circle of stones in a small clearing where the moonlight pooled like spilled milk. The stones were black, smooth, unnaturally placed—too perfect for nature, too crude for men. Clementine remembered the stories: a circle binds, but words unloose. She had no candles, no blood, no Latin. What she had were the letters her sister Eliza had taught her to trace in the dust with a stick—E-L-I-Z-A, then J-O-S-H-U-A, then M-A-R-T-H-A, and finally C-L-E-M-E-N-T-I-N-E. Four names. Four graves. She drew them large, each letter deep, packing the clay until the names stood proud like headstones. Then she knelt in the center, pulled the bone knife from her waistband, and cut her palm. The blood welled dark in the moonlight. She let it drip onto the packed earth between the names, where the stones’ shadow made a cruciform shape.

“I know you’re here,” she said, her voice thin but steady. “I know you listen to children. Because children are the ones who still believe you answer.”

The air grew heavy. A wind rose—not from the plains, but from *beneath*. The stones hummed. The blood on the ground shivered, then darkened, pulling itself into a shape like ink spilled in water. It coiled. Thickened. Grew limbs—long, skeletal fingers that flexed in the moonlight, then a torso draped in shadow, a head crowned with antlers that were not bone but living darkness, curling like charred oak. Its eyes were pits of ember, its mouth a slit without teeth, only a slow, cold breath that fogged the air.

It did not speak. It *unfolded*.

“You are small,” it said, and the voice was not heard but felt—in the marrow, in the roots of teeth, in the space between heartbeats. “Small things break easily.”

“I don’t break,” Clementine said. She wiped her bloody palm on her skirt. “I want you to find the men who came to Henderson’s. The ones with the smoke-stained bandanas. The one who rode the gray with the white sock. I want their names. I want their homes. And I want them to burn like my family did.”

The demon tilted its head. The antlers cast shifting shadows on the canyon wall behind it. “Revenge is a currency spent by the living. You are not yet dead, but you walk like her.” It pointed a finger of smoke toward the name MARTHA. “She feared the dark. You do not.”

“She didn’t have a knife,” Clementine said. “She didn’t have a pact.”

The demon smiled—if that black rent in its face could be called a smile. “Ah. So you believe in contracts. Good. I like that. But contracts require equivalents. I do not work for gratitude, or tears, or even hate. I work for *weight*. What will you give me, little girl, to balance the scale?”

Clementine thought of the orphanage: gray porridge, stiff bunks, the matron’s handprint on her cheek when she cried for her mother. She thought of the prairie nights, so vast and empty they made her ribs ache. She thought of the way the stars looked when you stared until your eyes watered—distant, indifferent, beautiful.

“My life,” she said.

The demon paused. It had expected bargaining. Tears. Promises of future sins. Not this clean, sharp offering laid bare on the tongue of silence.

“Not yet,” it murmured. “But soon. And not all at once. That would be… inefficient.”

“I don’t care about efficiency,” Clementine said. “I care about justice.”

“Justice is a word for courts and coffins. I deal in balance.” The demon extended a hand—black as obsidian, yet solid, real. “I will give them nightmares that peel the skin from their dreams. I will turn their horses lame, their whiskey sour, their guns misfire. I will make them see your mother’s face in every shadow, hear your brother’s laugh in the wind that howls through their rafters. They will lose their land, their gold, their friends. They will be haunted until they are hollow. And when the last of them hangs himself from a rafter in a barn full of ghosts… then I come for you.”

It was not a threat. It was a ledger.

“I accept,” Clementine said. She pressed her bleeding palm flat to the earth within the stone circle. The demon’s shadow-hand met hers. There was no heat, no cold—only a terrible suction, like the world breathing in. When she pulled away, the blood was gone. The ground was dry. The stones hummed a final chord and fell silent.

The demon did not vanish. It simply *wasn’t there* anymore, as if it had never been separate from the night itself.

Clementine walked home. She did not run. She did not look back.

Three weeks passed. Then the first sign: a smoke rider’s horse was found wandering ten miles east of Devil’s Gorge, its eyes rolled white, its flanks striped with raw, weeping welts as if raked by claws too large for any known beast. Then the saloon piano in Cedar Fork began playing *Shall We Gather at the River* at midnight, though no one touched the keys. The barkeep swore he saw the ghost of a little girl in a torn blue dress dancing barefoot on the sawdust floor.

Then the letters came.

Not to the men themselves at first—but to their wives. Scratched onto leather scraps, pinned to laundry with thorns. *He dreams of fire. He smells blood that isn’t his. He wakes screaming the name Martha.* Another: *Your husband’s boots are full of sand from a grave that does not exist. His revolver is cold where it should be warm. He cannot sleep on his back anymore. Something watches.*

Clementine did not sign them. She didn’t need to. The demon understood brand.

The first man died not by bullet, but by drowning—in a barrel of rainwater. The coroner called it a fit, but the undertaker whispered of water in the lungs and marks around the throat like wet rope. The second man was torn apart by his own hounds, which had turned on him in the yard, snapping and snarling at empty air above his head. The third—the one with the gray horse and the white sock—disappeared. His horse returned riderless, hooves crusted with red clay not found within fifty miles. A week later, his boots were discovered nailed to a cottonwood tree beside the Sweetwater Creek, filled with black stones from the gorge. Inside each boot, written in what looked like soot and blood, was a single name: *Eliza. Joshua. Martha. Clementine.*

The posse that rode out for him never returned. Their bodies were found scattered along the dry wash, stripped of their badges and guns, their faces frozen in expressions not of pain, but of profound, animal terror. No wounds. No blood. Just the look of a man who has seen his own death walking toward him—and knows it wears his daughter’s face.

Clementine stayed in the old Henderson place, though the walls were charred and the roof leaked. She swept the ashes into patterns on the floor. She spoke to the empty chairs at the table. She listened at night—not for coyotes, but for the absence of them. When the silence deepened, she knew the demon was near. Not seen. Not heard. But felt, like the pressure before a storm.

She began to change. Not in body, but in presence. The other orphans who came scavenging through the ruins fled when they saw her standing alone in the doorway, her shadow unnaturally long even at noon. The matron from Cedar Fork crossed herself when Clementine passed on the road. Men who’d once tipped their hats now spurred their horses aside. Children whispered that she didn’t eat, that her breath sometimes smelled of ozone after a lightning storm, that her eyes glinted red for a heartbeat when the light hit them wrong.

She did not correct them.

She saved her voice for the nights she walked to the edge of town, where the stars pooled thickest. She spoke to the darkness between them.

“Tell me,” she would say. “Have they dreamed of the fire yet?”

And the wind would answer—not with words, but with the scent of burning hair, or the distant crackle of embers, or the sound of a child weeping in a language no living tongue remembered.

She knew the debt was coming. She felt it in the hollowing of her chest, in the way food had begun to taste like ash, in the dreams where her hands were cold and black and her reflection in the creek had no face. But she also knew something else: the demon had not lied. It had not twisted her words. It had delivered *exactly* what she’d asked for—not swift death, but slow unmaking. Justice as erosion. Vengeance as gravity.

And in that, she found a terrible kind of comfort.

The last smoke rider, the one who’d led the raid, was found sitting on a rock in the middle of the desert, miles from any trail. He was alive, but his mind was gone. He rocked back and forth, muttering a name over and over—not his own, not a woman’s, but a child’s, spoken in a voice that cracked like dry mud: *Clemmie… Clemmie…* He died three days later, babbling of a girl who stood in the flames with him, who held his hand as he burned, and who smiled with eyes like dying stars.

Clementine watched the burial from a distance. When the men left, she walked to the grave. It was shallow, the dirt still loose. She did not dig. Instead, she placed a single smooth stone from the gorge’s edge on the mound. Then another. And another. By morning, the grave was ringed with black stones, each one warm to the touch even in the chill dawn.

That night, the demon came for her—not in the gorge, but in her dreams. It stood at the foot of her bed, its antlers brushing the ceiling of a room that had no walls.

“Balance,” it said.

“I know,” Clementine whispered. She was not afraid. Her hands were already turning translucent, the bones inside visible like branches in winter. “Take what is owed.”

The demon tilted its head, as if surprised by her calm. “Most scream. Some bargain. Few… prepare the ledger themselves.”

“I kept my word,” she said. “They are all unmade. Their names are dust. Their homes are haunted husks. Their children will tell stories of the Henderson curse for a hundred years.”

“Not their children,” the demon said. “*Yours.*”

It reached for her. Not with claws, but with a hand of starlight and shadow. And as its fingers closed around her wrist, she felt not pain, but release. Like the uncorking of a deep, old wine.

“I take not your life, Clementine Morgan,” it breathed into the hollow of her mind. “I take your *absence*. From this moment, you will be forgotten by all who ever held you in memory. Your name will slip from tongues. Your face will blur in photographs. The graves at Henderson’s will grow barren—no flowers, no weeds, only smooth earth as if no one had ever lain beneath. You will walk the earth, but no one will see you. No one will hear you. You will be a ghost not of death, but of erasure. And in that silence, you will serve me.”

She smiled then—a small, fierce thing. “Then I will be the ghost that haunts their memory,” she said. “I will be the chill in the blood of their descendants. I will be the name they dare not speak. You do not take my life. You make it immortal.”

The demon paused. For the first time in longer than the earth had turned, it felt… hesitation. Not fear, but the shock of encountering a soul that understood the true cost of its currency.

“Very well,” it said at last. “Be the echo in the silence. Be the scar that never heals. Go now. Walk. And let your forgetting be the ruin upon which their peace crumbles.”

When Clementine awoke, the sun was rising. A sparrow landed on the windowsill—and flew straight through her. She looked down. Her hands were solid again. But when she walked into town, the blacksmith did not nod. The general store owner stared through her as if she were a trick of the light. Her name was not spoken. Her face was not remembered.

She was gone. And in her place stood a silence that grew like a stain.

Years later, when the railroad came and the old stories began to fade, they would still speak of the Henderson Ghost—not as a spirit, but as a *presence*. A sudden cold in summer. A child’s laugh with no child near. A name half-remembered at the edge of sleep, then gone. And sometimes, on moonless nights, a girl with braids darker than the gorge’s shadows would stand on a hill overlooking the town, her eyes reflecting not the stars, but the slow, satisfied burn of justice served.

She had not broken. She had become the breaking.

And as the demon watched from the spaces between seconds, it understood: the girl had not summoned it. It had summoned her. And in the end, the most dangerous pact is not the one signed in blood—but the one signed in the absolute clarity of a child who knows exactly what she is paying, and pays it anyway.

Because some debts are not meant to be settled.

Only carried. Forever. Like the night itself.

samples.prompt: Someone who was named "Science"is not pleased at all the bodies they have been getting as donations.
samples.output:
The first time Science opened the chilled stainless-steel drawer and saw what lay inside, they almost laughed. Almost. Because the name *Science* had been stamped onto their birth certificate like a brand, a cosmic joke they’d spent thirty-two years resenting in silence. But this—this was something else. This was the universe leaning in to whisper, *You think you’re special? Here’s what people give the thing they pretend to worship.*

The body on the table wasn’t a body. It was a taxidermy accident. Skin like cured leather stretched over disjointed bones; the left femur had been sawed unevenly, leaving a jagged crown of bone exposed, flecked with dried marrow like rust on iron. The lungs were collapsed sacks, deflated as if exhaled centuries ago. And the eyes—oh, the eyes. Instead of the expected glass prosthetics or respectful closure, someone had inserted two mismatched marbles: one cobalt blue, chipped at the edge; the other a cloudy, off-white glass, the kind used in cheap fish-tank decor. Science ran a gloved finger along the suture line of the abdomen. The stitches weren’t surgical. They were thick, black fishing thread, knotted with the clumsy enthusiasm of an amateur. Whoever had prepared this donation had done so not out of reverence for science, but out of contempt for the dead—or perhaps for the living who would have to look at it.

Science’s real name was a syllable too close to obscenity, a sound their mother had spat into the hospital registration form, drunk on grief and irony. “Call her Science,” she’d slurred to the admitting nurse, whose pen hesitated over the line. “Since none of you *believe* in it anymore.” Science had grown up inheriting that bitterness, the name a constant reminder of expectation unmet—of a world that invoked their namesake only when convenient, while gutting its core principles for ideology, profit, or convenience.

Now, as head of the Anatomical Gifts Division at Veridian University Medical Center, Science was the final gatekeeper. Every donated body passed through their hands before entering the curriculum or research stream. They had seen cancer eat through spines like acid. They had traced the delicate latticework of Alzheimer’s in brains suspended in formaldehyde. They had even accepted the quiet dignity of advanced decomposition, the bodies that arrived soft and fragrant with decay, because decay *was* science—a slow, inevitable dance with entropy.

But this? This was vandalism masquerading as donation.

The paperwork listed the donor as “E. Pendergast, retired.” Cause of death: “cardiac arrest.” No notes. No special requests. Just a signature scrawled on a form that promised, *I give my body to the advancement of knowledge.* Science had read that line thousands of times. Each signature felt like a tiny act of faith, or desperation, or penance. Pendergast’s felt like a dare.

They unzipped the body bag of the next arrival. An elderly woman, perhaps seventy-eight, with thin white hair matted to the pillow. Except her torso had been replaced with a crude wooden box, nailed shut. Science lifted the edge of the sheet. The box was hollow where her abdomen should have been, the edges splintered, as if someone had used a handsaw in a garage. The ribcage had been sawn open, but instead of organs, there was only packed sawdust and a single, withered dandelion stem taped to the inside.

Science stood perfectly still. The cold room hummed. Their breath fogged the air, a small, human protest against the absurdity. They didn’t flinch at death. They flinched at *farce*.

The third body arrived the next Tuesday. A man in his fifties, according to the file. But when Science cut through the layers of formaldehyde-soaked gauze wrapped around his head, they found not a face, but a polished brass mask molded to the contours of his skull. The eye slits were drilled perfectly, the mouth a smooth oval with no teeth, no tongue. Inside the oral cavity, someone had placed a folded slip of paper. Science unfolded it. Scrawled in red ink: *LOOK CLOSER. YOU’LL SEE NOTHING.*

That was the moment Science stopped cataloging anomalies and began compiling a dossier. Not medical. Forensic. Emotional.

The donations kept coming. A body with all its muscles replaced by coiled springs and rubber bands, labeled “MUSCULAR DYSFUNCTION CASE STUDY.” A donor whose brain had been excised and replaced with a tangle of copper wires, resistors, and a single green LED that blinked at a rate just shy of perceptible. The accompanying note: “THEY SAID I HAD NO MIND LEFT. PROVE THEM WRONG.”

Science didn’t sleep. They paced the gleaming corridors of the anatomy lab at 2 a.m., the preserved bodies in their rows like an audience waiting for a performance that would never satisfy. They began to recognize the signatures—the same jagged capital ‘S’, the same ink smudges left by a trembling hand, the same faint scent of camphor and turpentine clinging to the formsheets.

It wasn’t random. It was a campaign.

A theology professor once told Science that naming a child was an act of possession. “You don’t just give a name,” he’d said. “You stake a claim. You say, *This is what you are.*” Science had always rejected that claim. They were not a method. Not a discipline. Not a clean, sterile ideal. They were a woman who woke with headaches, who loved bitter coffee and hated the smell of bleach, who cried during reruns of *Nova* when the narrator described a neuron firing like a tiny, lonely star.

But these donors—they had listened. They had heard the name *Science* and understood it not as a person, but as a void. A blank altar. And they were filling it with their refuse.

The university administration dismissed Science’s concerns as professional sensitivity. “These people are eccentric,” said Dean Hollings. “Grieving families sometimes arrange… personalized send-offs. It’s harmless.”

“It’s not harmless,” Science replied, their voice low and steady, a scalpel of tone. “It’s a desecration of trust. When someone signs this form”—they tapped the donor agreement—“they are entrusting us with the most intimate residue of human existence. They are saying, *I was here. Study what remains.* Not, *I was here. Now make me a joke.*”

Hollings shrugged. “If it bothers you so much, reassign them. Put them in the engineering department’s materials stress lab. They can test tensile strength on brass masks and spring-loaded spines.”

Science stared. “That’s not what bodies are for.”

“Isn’t it?” Hollings smiled, the kind of smile that ends conversations. “Everything breaks. Everything deforms. Why not quantify the poetry?”

That night, Science stayed after hours. They wheeled Pendergast’s wooden-chested form to the dissection table, turned on the overheads, and began to document. Not for the curriculum. For the record.

They measured the box: 28 cm x 22 cm x 15 cm. Not anatomically accurate. Not even internally consistent. The thoracic cavity was too shallow for a real ribcage; the lumbar region curved unnaturally. They photographed the dandelion stem, cross-referenced it with local flora databases. *Taraxacum officinale.* Common dandelion. Symbol of resilience, wish-granting, childhood. Irony, perhaps. Or accusation.

The next body was the one with copper wires for a brain. Science connected a multimeter to the circuit. The LED pulsed at 0.8 Hz—forty-eight times a minute. A heartbeat’s ghost. They traced the wires: no inputs, no outputs. A closed system. A mind feeding only itself, trapped in a blinking soliloquy. Science remembered Pendergast’s teacher in high school, Mr. Lowell, who used to say, “A circuit without a load is just anxiety made metal.”

These donors weren’t giving themselves to science. They were giving science *back* to itself—a mirror cracked and reassembled with rusted wire.

Then came the seventh body. A young woman, twenty-three, donor form filled out in elegant cursive. *I was told knowledge was light,* it read. *So I give you my shadow.*

When Science unzipped the bag, they understood. The body was present, but translucent. Not preserved in formaldehyde, but suspended in a clear gel that refracted light into prismatic fragments. Organs were visible, but dimmed, as if viewed through deep water. The heart was there, beating at a visible 40 bpm—but it was made of glass, filled with swirling ink that never settled. The bones glowed faintly with bioluminescent algae cultured in the marrow cavity.

This wasn’t vandalism. This was prophecy.

Science touched the gel. Cool. Alive, in its way. The algae responded to pressure, glowing brighter where their fingers pressed, like stars winking into existence. They realized: this body wasn’t useless. It was *impossible*. It defied categorization. It was art. It was protest. It was a question etched in flesh: *What are you going to do with me now?*

That night, Science didn’t just document. They wrote a letter. Not to the dean. Not to the ethics board. To the donors. To the ghost in the signatures, the hand that chose the dandelion, the brass mask, the blinking wire.

*You think I’m disappointed?* Science typed, fingers trembling. *You think I don’t see what you’re doing? You’re not giving me corpses. You’re giving me indictments. You’re naming the thing I’ve spent my life serving, and showing me how hollow the name has become. You’re the ones who still believe. Not in data, but in the sacredness of asking. You’re not mocking science. You’re reminding it what questions feel like when you’ve forgotten how to ask them without a grant proposal or a publication deadline.*

Science printed the letter and placed it on the chest of the translucent woman. Beneath the glass heart, the ink swirled like blood.

The next donation was different. No body arrived. Instead, a single manila envelope. Inside, a key to a storage unit in Poughkeepsie, and a note: *Open it. Then decide if you still want to dissect.*

Science drove north in a rental car, the dawn gray and quiet. The unit was dust and silence. In the center sat a wooden crate, nailed shut. Using a crowbar from the trunk, Science pried it open.

Inside was a human skeleton, articulated with brass rods at the joints, wired together like a marionette. But the skull was detachable. Lifted off, it revealed not bone, but a nest of handwritten journals, bound in leather. The first page, in the same jagged hand: *To Science: You asked for bodies. Here is mine, reassembled. Not for study. For conversation. Read me when you’re tired of cutting.*

Science sat on the concrete floor and opened the top journal. It wasn’t medical history. It was a life—Pendergast’s, they assumed. Pages on his failed marriage, his love for astronomy, his shame at being fired from a pharmaceutical lab for refusing to falsify data. He described watching his father die slowly in a hospital, tubes like vines strangling him, doctors speaking over him as if he were a faulty machine. “That’s when I understood,” Pendergast had written. “Science isn’t the scalpel. It’s the hand that holds it. And sometimes the hand trembles. Sometimes it cuts out of fear. Sometimes it cuts out of love. But if you forget it’s a hand, you become the blade.”

Science read until sunset bled through the high window. They didn’t dissect a single body that week. Instead, they requisitioned archival space. They began labeling the donations not as “specimens” but as “correspondences.” The brass-masked man now sat beside a display on Victorian mourning automata. The spring-augmented spine was mounted next to early prosthesis patents. The gel-suspended woman was placed under a light that cycled through wavelengths to make her glow like a slow nebula.

Students started lingering. Not med students, but artists, poets, philosophy majors. One left a sketch of the dandelion taped to the wooden box, captioned: *Roots in sawdust still reach for sun.*

Science didn’t stop the dissections. They didn’t halt the research. But they changed the terms. Every body now received a contextual file: not just cause of death, but cause of *life*. Not just weight and height, but favorite books, regrets, the last song they’d hummed. The engineering department got its tensile tests—but only after Science attached a narrative: *This spine supported thirty-two years of teaching third grade. It bent when she carried her granddaughter on her hip. It broke when the cancer came. Now it holds 1,200 Newtons before yielding. Respect the tension.*

One evening, Science stood before Pendergast’s articulated skeleton, its brass joints catching the lab’s overhead light. They didn’t see a specimen. They saw a man who had spent his life building models of the universe, only to leave behind a model of science’s soul—exposed, rewired, still pulsing with questions.

Science lifted the skull. The journals were lighter than expected. As if the words had eaten the paper from within.

That night, Science signed their own donor form. Not with their real name. Not with their title.

They printed a single word in block letters:

**SCIENCE**

Then, in the special requests section, they wrote: *Please return the body to the earth unaltered. No preservatives. No incisions. Let the worms and rain and time conduct the experiment. I want to see what decomposition looks like when no one is watching for results.*

And below that, one last line:

*If you must study me, read the journals first. Especially page 83. I left a dandelion there. It’s not a metaphor. It’s a calibration.*

When the form was filed, Science leaned back in their chair and closed their eyes. For the first time in years, the silence didn’t hum. It listened.

The donations never stopped. But they changed. The sarcasm thinned. The next body arrived with clean incisions, but tucked beneath the ribcage was a small, polished river stone, and a note: *I was afraid of the dark. Now I help you see.*

Another: a retired physicist, his brain intact, but with a USB drive sutured to his scalp. The drive contained one file: a video of him whispering, *Ask better questions.*
